Getting started

Learn how to compile the source code, builds the theme and documentation, and more.

Introduction

Quick start

Download and try to apply the precompiled theme (dist/theme.xml) to your blog.

Download

Download

Contents

Once downloaded, unzip the compressed folder and you’ll see something like this:

[root project directory]
├── dist
│   ├── docs
│   └── theme.xml
└── src
    ├── _docs
    ├── _js
    ├── _scss
    ├── _xml
    ├── tmp
    ├── config.base.json
    ├── config.docs.json
    ├── config.theme.json
    └── theme.xml
File / DirectoryDescription
distThe dist folder includes precompiled theme, as well as compiled and minified documentation files.
srcThese are the source code that will be compiled into dist.
src/_docsThe source code for documentation (dist/docs).
src/_jsThe source code for JavaScript (src/tmp/js/bundle.js).
src/_scssThe source code for CSS (src/tmp/css/bundle.css).
src/_xmlThe Blogger XML that can be mixed and matched by your theme.
src/tmpCSS and JS are compiled into this folder.
src/config.base.json
src/config.docs.json
src/config.theme.json
Configuration data.
src/skin.css
src/template-skin.css
The main stylesheet. Styles in skin.css are defined within the <b:skin> tag. You can use the skin variables.
Styles in template-skin.css are defined within the <b:template-skin> tag.
src/theme.xmlThe main file for the theme. All the compiled CSS and JS, and the XML partials will be included in this file.
Other files/foldersBeyond that, any other included file and directory provides support for packages, license information, and development.

Step by Step Tutorial

The goal of this tutorial is to take you from having some development experience to building your first theme.

  1. Download. Once downloaded, unzip the compressed folder and rename bloggerable-dist to your project name.
  2. Run through the tooling setup below to use our build system.
  3. Configure theme src/config.theme.json.
  4. Configure docs src/config.docs.json.
    • Important: change title and downloadUrl.
  5. Customize the theme and documentation to suit your needs.
  6. Run grunt to build your changes.
  7. To preview your changes, apply the new compiled theme (dist/theme.xml) to your blog. Reload the local documentation in your browser to preview documentation changes.
  8. Done? (Yes: next) / (No: back to number 2).
  9. Edit src/_docs/getting-started.md: remove this section (Step by Step Tutorial).
  10. Update README.md for your theme.
  11. Version control: You can use Git for your theme development (this is not required, but will help to manage changes to source code over time).
    1. git init
    2. git add .
    3. git commit -m "Initial commit"
    4. Push your theme source code to GitHub or other services for Git.
  12. To release your theme, run grunt release, this command will zip your theme and the source (exclude: .git, .zip, node_modules).
  13. Share your theme (the zip file).

Tooling setup

We uses Grunt for its build system. To use our build system, you’ll need the source files and Node. Follow these steps:

  1. Download and install Node.js, which we use to manage our dependencies.
  2. Install grunt-cli globally with npm install -g grunt-cli.
  3. Navigate to the root project directory and run npm install to install our local dependencies listed in package.json.

When completed, you’ll be able to run the various commands provided from the command line.

Using Grunt commands

Our Gruntfile.js includes the following commands and tasks:

TaskDescription
gruntgrunt creates the dist directory with compiled files.
grunt watchWatches the source files and automatically building them whenever you save.
grunt releaseSame as grunt plus it zip your theme and the source (exclude: .git, .zip, node_modules).

Local documentation

You can run the documentation locally via Grunt commands:

  1. From the root project directory, run grunt docs-serve in the command line.
  2. Open http://localhost:9001 in your browser.

Templating

We uses grunt-bake for creating modular files in order to ease the process while in development.

Partials

For example, the grunt-bake tag that can be used to include the partial in src/_xml/file.xml:

src/theme.xml

// Relative to the file
<!--(bake _xml/file.xml)-->

// Relative to the "src" path
<!--(bake /_xml/file.xml)-->

Configuration

Configuration data:

  1. src/config.base.json
  2. src/config.docs.json
  3. src/config.theme.json

You can access the data in:

  • src/theme.xml
  • src/skin.css
  • src/template-skin.css
  • src/_xml
  • src/_scss
  • src/_js
  • src/_docs

Access the data:

  • config.base.json - access the data using {{ base.dataName }}
  • config.docs.json - access the data using {{ docs.dataName }}
  • config.theme.json - access the data using {{ theme.dataName }}

Example:

config.theme.json

{
  "example": "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet"
}

your-file.xml

<p>{{ theme.example }}.</p>

Output:

<p>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.</p>

Learn more

Learn more about using grunt-bake by reading its documentation.
